title: Thank You Professor Margaret Robinson
text:
Thank You Professor Margaret Robinson

"The best thing for being sad," said Merlin, "is to learn something."
It's a quote you've shared with us before, and one that feels especially fitting now. Throughout your years at Mount Holyoke, you've lived those words, teaching with brilliance, compassion, and an unwavering belief in your students.
Having taught nearly every math course at Mount Holyoke, you've touched countless lives across generations of students. You've been more than a teacher, you've been a mentor, a steadfast advocate, and a constant source of warmth and wisdom. You believed in us before we believed in ourselves.
Thank you for everything you have done for us and Mount Holyoke. As you step into this new chapter, we wanted to share a few messages from those lucky enough to learn from you. Each one carries our deepest gratitude, admiration, and love.







Dear Margaret, Thank you for everything! Your enthusiasm as a teacher is infectious. Your natural curiousity and kindness made you so approachable and such a good mentor. Your amazing memory of prior students and desire to help others were invaluable as a networking resource for students and alums. I will miss seeing you on campus, but I know you will make the most of your time to meet new challenges and learn new things! I hope you have a wonderful retirement, filled with lots of time with family, new projects, and joy. Love, Mary Fleischli




Your love of math is infectious. I am deeply grateful for how much you care about your students and how dedicated you are to being an impactful teacher.




Thank you for everything you‚Äôve done for us! Your dedication to teaching, research, and mentorship has made a huge difference for me and many other students at Mount Holyoke College. I still remember your smiles when I first met you under the camp during orientation. I feel so lucky to have met you and to be able to attend your class. Your passion to maths inspires me and motivates me a lot üíì




I'm an advisee of Professor Robinson from the Class of 2024. She has had a profound impact on both my academic journey and my personal life. Under her guidance, I was first introduced to the world of Mathematics, and she played a pivotal role in shaping my path. I miss her greatly!




Congratulations on retirement! Thank you so much for sharing your love of math and for all do the guidance, insights, and opportunities your provided. You helped make the Mount Holyoke Math Department a wonderful place to learn. 
-Rae Tomarkin




Thank you for your enthusiasm and care! You made a real difference in my life.  Your classes were excellent, ensuring that I was not afraid to take on any math problem. You willingly gave me a recommendation when I came to you 2 years after graduation after having not talked to you in years, which helped me get my Masters and my current career.  Never doubt your amazing impact, and I hope you enjoy every bit of the fun of this next phase in your life.




Hi!!!! I came to MHC with an AA, concentration math. I wanted to pursue astrophysics, but signed up for all the higher level math I could find as well. You were an inspiration. You made me feel like a math minor was possible, even with a "double major" like astronomy and physics. (I also had a French Minor!) I have memories of your office, chatting like adults. I'm so grateful to you. Especially because the reason I likely got into MHC was a heartfelt recommendation from Ellen Ortyl, who had worked on campus. She had connected me with Laurie Kamins, whose lovely kids I had the pleasure of babysitting for! I'm just very grateful for your existence, and how you welcomed me into the fold as a transfer student from Cape Cod. <3 Happy Retirement!!!!




Professor Robinson, I recently heard the news of your retirement, and I wanted to take a moment to express my gratitude and share your lasting impact on me, even after 10+ years post graduating Mount Holyoke. 

I still remember your classes vividly. Beyond the equations and proofs, you taught me how to approach problems with curiosity and persistence‚Äîskills that continue to serve me well in my personal and professional life. Your passion for mathematics and your ability to make complex concepts engaging left a lasting impression on me, and I‚Äôm so grateful to have been one of your students. Every time I've had the chance to come back on campus, I make sure to stop by your office on the 4th floor. You've taught and inspired generations of students, and I'm proud to be one of them. 

I wish you all the best as you enjoy this well-deserved next phase‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs filled with travel, new hobbies, or just some well-earned rest.

Thank you!!
Kleida Martiro
Class of 2014




Dearest Margaret, 

I miss you so much and wanted to share a quick update about my life. 
After graduating from Isenberg in 2016, I didn't get a chance to say goodbye as I was expecting my first child in May.  In the Fall of 2018, I started teaching at Santa Clara University's Finance department, where I spent four years before joining Meta as a data scientist.  My role involves developing new methodologies to measure top advertisers.  

I'm grateful for your guidance and support throughout my journey.  Without you, I wouldn't be where I am today.  You played a significant role not only as my professor, but also as a mentor and guardian to help guide my paths forward.  I feel so lucky to have been one of your students and advisees.  

Sending you love from the sunny Bay Area!  Please visit us whenever you can. Thank you immensely for everything!  Your impact on my life is immeasurable. 

With heartfelt gratitude,
~Ning Pu (Class of 2007)
Email: ningpu62@gmail.com 
Phone: (413) 335-9291




Dear Professor Robinson, Thank you for inspiring a love for mathematics in us!! -- A proud fellow mathematician named K Kaya




Dear Margaret,  this is Gina Leung from class of 2012. I was a dance and mathematics major. Thank you for being such an inspiring professor, and also for coming to all my dance concerts! It really meant a lot to me. I am still in the UK. I have 3 (soon to be 4!) sons. You might be interested to know that my eldest son (6) loves math and loves doing math challenges. I leave a maths textbook laying around and he would read it himself and come ask me for help and I always get so excited when he does! He has taught himself long division reading that book himself. Even my 4 year old knows all his times table! Enjoy your last semester and enjoy your well deserved retirement. Best wishes, Gina.




Dear Professor Margaret:

I recently heard about your upcoming retirement, and I couldn‚Äôt let this moment pass without telling you that you are, without a doubt, the best professor in the world. Your passion for teaching and your unwavering support for your students have left an indelible mark on me.

Your classes were not just educational; they were transformative. You taught me how to think critically, explore boldly, and believe in my abilities. I will always be grateful for the lessons you shared and the encouragement you gave.

As you step into this exciting new chapter of life, I hope it is filled with as much joy and inspiration as you‚Äôve given to your students over the years. Thank you for everything, and please know how much of a difference you‚Äôve made in my life. Wishing you all the happiness in the world!

Best regards, 
Tong Wu




Thank you for bringing fun math class to us! The discrete mathematics you taught is the most engaging and my favorite math class I have ever taken in all these years. I also heard updates from my friends about you and thank you for being so supportive! Finally, I hope you can enjoy your life after retirement. Thank you again for everything!




Dear Dr Robinson, Thank you for making the Math Department such a welcoming and stimulating place on campus and for your radiating such positivity in all your interactions with students. I wish you all the best for your retirement. Cheers, Lilla Zollei '99




Dear Professor Robinson, 

Thank you for your guidance and inspiration on calculation over the years! I was not a student in your class, but you still answer my questions with kindness and patience. I‚Äôm deeply grateful for the encouragement in the math world. I will miss your presence at Moho, and wish you all the best in your retirement and beyond. 

Best regards, 
Yizhen Liu
 Class 2020




I hope you have a wonderful retirement! Thank you so much for your care for us in the Summer of ‚Äò97 REU group, and the road trip we took to the Joint Mathematics Meetings in Baltimore. Your joyous and enthusiastic attitude toward mathematics is something I will always remember about you.  Thanks so much for all your work on behalf of Mount Holyoke students! Best wishes.  - Margret Hjalmarson ‚Äò98




Dear professor Robinson, Congratulations on your well-deserved retirement! Thank you for your years of insightful guidance, and passion for math, as well as your mentorship in my past summer REU research. I wish you all the best in your next chapter filled with relaxation and new adventures.  - Caiyun Zhu 2015




Professor Robinson I have never had a class with you and yet you‚Äôve had an impact on me as a person and I‚Äôve heard only good things about you from everyone who‚Äôs had the honor to take classes with you!! I congratulate you on your career as a professor and a person. Wishing you the best always! Sohini Bhatia ‚Äò23




Happy retirement! I'm forever grateful to be one of your student!




Dear Margaret, thank you for being such a wonderful advisor and professor! Your math classes were so joyful, and your support was instrumental in the development of my own mathematical career! .  It was also such a treat to come visit and speak at the seminar this year :)  Best, Spencer




You were so instrumental in my MoHo journey. Thank you for everything you did to encourage us and get through college :).




Thank you for everything you did to inspire and encourage my passion for mathematics! I know your presence at MHC has had profound effects on thousands of lives. Enjoy this time of celebration!!




It was great seeing you at Reunion this past May and I hope to attend your celebration.




Your love for math and teaching is deeply touching, I wish I had a professor like you back in middle school and high school, for all subjects if I could. Thank you Margaret for showing me pure integrity and amazing work ethics.




Dear Prof Robinson/ Margaret

I can't believe that you are retiring. It seems just like yesterday we were all on Skinner Green with your two little girls aged 2 and 4. You have been an inspiration to me and many other MHC students who have crossed your path Majors and Non Majors.  From your outing club stories, and your immense enthusiasm for Mathematics and life in general and it was delight to be in any of your math classes. THANK YOU for all the support you have given me over our 30 years of friendship.  I look forward to seeing you in the Spring during my 30th College Reunion.  In Gratitude and with Much Love - Cristina Ilangakoon Class of 1995 Math Major




Thank you so much for supporting me after I graduated from MoHo and gave me suggestions that really helped me to find the direction for my application. Every time talking to you, I learned a lot! Thank you for your contribution to the school and your passion for math has always inspired me!




Dear Professor Robinson- this is Heidi Zhang, class of 2021 who served as your teaching assistant during Covid period when everything was online! I think I didn‚Äôt get a chance to take your classes and our most direct interaction is being your TA. However, I always saw you in campus and in Clapp, and my friend Amelia Tran always mentioned you to me! In my memory, you are always patient and encouraging; your smile would melt the South Hadley snow. I think if I didn‚Äôt join Mount Holyoke, I probably would not pick math as major. It was the great culture math department has and the lovely professors as you made me interested in diving deeper in this subject. Due to my study aboard second half of my junior year, and covid during my senior year, my on campus live abruptly ended, which is still a great pity and pain. But reading it from a different angle, I feel like this pity will deepen my memory of the priceless math studying and campus life in Mount Holyoke. And I really want to thank you for writing me a lovely card and sending me a MHC hat as thank-you gift after serving as your TA in my senior year. Wish you have an amazing journey after retirement and look forward to seeing you again in the near future!




Dear Professor Robinson - congratulations and happy retirement. I was in your Calc and Linear Algebra classes, and really enjoyed them! Your passion for the subject, dedication to us the students, and empathy shone through. I wish you all the best on new adventures and wanted you to know that you made an impact on my life. Thank you so much! 
- Sundus Husain (2008)




Professor - congratulations on retiring! Thank you so much for being my advisor for four years at MHC. To an 18-year girl, first time studying outside of her native land, you are more than a mentor and a professor, dare to say that, as if I was fortunate enough at that time, to gain a mother-like figure at MHC. Wish you all the best for your future endeavors after retirement. The best is yet to come.




Hi Margaret, this is Jingyi. I missed you so much! I'll definitely come back for your retirement celebration in the spring. üò≠üò≠üò≠




Prof. Margaret, Congratulations on your retirement! I still remember our office hours and how passionate you were in maths and teaching. You also had so much patience with me and all other students. I feel fortunate to have been one of your students. Wishing you joy and relaxation in this new chapter of your life! Hope I make it to the campus to see you next year before you truly retire! 
Warmest regards, Weiding Wu




Some of my fondest memories at Mount Holyoke have been in your class and office hours. 
I took many of your classes, but particularly enjoyed your abstract algebra class. It really helped me see the beauty in patterns. You were always incredibly kind, caring, and patient. Thank you. 

Enjoy retirement! You're the best!




Congratulations!  What a legacy!




Hello,

Wow, cannot believe you time at Mount Holyoke is coming to end! MHC students and I were lucky to have you and I was especially lucky to have you as both my professor and advisor. Thank you for always being supportive, kind, and going above and beyond for each and every one of your students. Both you dedication and passion for students and mathematics made my math journey what it was! I hope you enjoyed all of your years there and are leaving knowing the impact that you made. I hope you feel accomplished in all of your work and research that you‚Äôve done over the years. Hope to stay in touch. Best of Luck!

Stephanie




Hi Professor Robinson,

Congratulations on your retirement!! Your linear algebra class I took was one of the toughest yet most fun classes I took at moho. I still remember how you would pop in when you saw me at TA hours in the night and would still offer to help solve problems. Thank you for your dedication to not just me but the 100s and more students who you‚Äôve helped over the years. I‚Äôm now a senior analyst at NERA economic consulting still doing some math on a daily basis haha! Wishing you only the very best in your retirement :) 

Best
Marihah Idroos (class of 2019)




Professor Robinson, What an amazing time at Mount Holyoke you have had. I will always remember my summer REU as some of the fondest times I had in college. I am so appreciative of all the guidance I received during that time. Your love and passion for math always came through in your classes; I am sure many more students feel the same. Cheers to a happy retirement! Adelyn




I took two classes with Professor Robinson. Her enthusiam about math and teaching created such a wonderful supporting environment for me to enjoy math without fear. I am forever grateful to her for her support and guidance.




With great gratitude for all the students whose lives you have transformed, as a brilliant educator, role model and incredible human being.  Thank you for all your years of service.  You have helped built confidence, careers and touched lives in ways you will never know.




Congratulations on your well-deserved retirement! I was very lucky to take your classes and had you as my adviser. Thank you and wish you a happy and fulfilling next chapter. Lu Li‚Äô13




Prof. Robinson, 20 years later, I still remember your passion for teaching and math. I also still remember the problem about coffee with milk that you gave us during a Differential Equations class, so I always add the milk first if I want my coffee to cool down faster. Wishing you a long and healthy retirement!




You were so kind and patient. Thank you for taking the time to teach us well.




Thank you for being such a remarkable mentor and role model! Your passion for teaching, kindness, and guidance have left an indelible mark on my academic journey and personal growth. I feel so fortunate to have been your student. I wish you a retirement full of joy, relaxation, and new adventures.  With deepest gratitude and warmest wishes, Ruilin




Your warmth and support has touched generations of students! Not sure I‚Äôd be where I am today without you! I know you‚Äôll find many pursuits to fill this next chapter! Miriam ‚Äò12




You really made me fall in love with math. I took Calculus I with you in my sophomore year and ended up deciding to major in math. You made the course more than just tedious calculations. Even afterwards you were always so helpful any time I emailed you for help. You‚Äôre an amazing person, and an even better professor and mentor. I was just working on a math homework assignment for my masters in AI, and it all started with taking Calculus with you. I wish you the absolute best!!




I am so excited and happy for Professor Robinson as she enters this exciting time in her life. Professor Robinson was such a wonderful professor and person during my time st MHC. Always so positive and encouraging, I loved having classes with her and inevitably left happier than I arrived. A genuinely kind and special person. I remember returning for a reunion years ago with my two children in tow. Not only was she so happy to connect with me she spent time with my kids teaching them some math wonders - they still remember and talk about that!

Wishing Professor Robinson the very best and thank her for all she has given to MHC and her students.




Your love for math inspired me to build the career that I have and share my love with my own daughters.  You are such a treasure and your impact is far reaching.  Thank you for all that you have done to further the field of mathematics and to create a space for women.




Congratulations!  It was a pleasure to serve as your TA and a math lab tutor... 25 years ago?  That math doesn't add up!  It ended up being great preparation for my career as a law librarian and legal research professor - it helped me learn the right questions to ask while getting students/users to a proper answer. (There's not always "the" right answer in legal research!)  Thank you for your dedication, and best wishes for a long, fulfilling retirement.
Suzanne Corriell, class of 2000 (statistics minor)




Professor Robinson! 

I want to thank you for all of the support you provided me in undergrad. You were not only an amazing advisor who supported me when I felt like I didn't know what I was doing, but an AWESOME math professor. You made math fun and your love & passion for the subject was always felt. Moreover, thank you for exposing me to different summer programs and just being a listening ear about anything. 

You are an asset to the MHC community, and I am so grateful that you were a part of my experience! 

Best,
Ashley Jimenez




Happy Retirement!! Thank you so much for your passion about Math, it has inspired me so much! I enjoyed taking your class a lot! --- Susan Wang




Margaret, you are such an amazing professor, and you will be greatly missed in MHC's math department! I absolutely loved having you as a professor during my time at MHC! You made math so fun, and I always looked forward to coming to class! You showed that you cared so much about each and every one of your students and truly wanted to see everyone succeed! You are a math professor that I think back on frequently as I pursue a Masters in secondary education in math. I strive to be as caring, excited, and knowledgeable of an educator as you! Wishing you all the best in what's to come next!




Thank you Professor Robinson. I wish you all the best for the next chapter.




Dear Margaret,

Congratulations on your retirement! I wanted to take a moment to thank you for the incredible impact you‚Äôve had on me. Your classes were both challenging and fun‚Äîan experience I‚Äôll always cherish. I‚Äôll never forget your laughter and the joy you brought to teaching. You are such a lovely person, and it was truly a privilege to learn from you.

Wishing you all the best as you begin this exciting new chapter.

Jenna Nichols 
Class of 2001




Dear Prof. Robinson,  although we haven't kept in touch after I graduated I often think of you. You are one of the best teacher I have had, always very approachable, kind and patient. I feel lucky to have you as my advisor while at MHC. My son loves reading the Palindrome book you gifted me on my graduation :) Wish you all the best for your life after MHC. 
Renu Ghale




Dear Professor Robinson - Thank you so much for fundamentally shaping how I problem solve. From Real Analysis to P-adic Analysis, you both challenged and supported me through the work and helped me work, think, and lead differently both at MHC and beyond. Best of luck as you enter this next phase of life! Cheers, Shwetha




Dear Professor Robinson,

You were such a valuable mentor to me in my time at Mount Holyoke. You were my advisor and my teacher, and you were a vital part of my enthusiasm for math and my decision to attend graduate school for mathematics. Your own enthusiasm was infectious, and your kindness was precious to me in moments when I was struggling. My time studying math has had a permanent impact on the way I think about and interact with the world, and I will always be grateful for it and for you.

I hope you have a wonderful time in retirement. Congratulations!

Sincerely,
Faye Sprague-Williams




Hi Margaret! I was one of your advisees that graduated in Dec ‚Äò21. Congratulations on your retirement! And thank you so much for all your help throughout the years! Thanks to your support, from taking your linear algebra class to writing my letter of recommendation for grad school, I‚Äôm now studying for my MPH Biostatistics & Epidemiology at CUNY School of Public Health while working as a Data Scientist at New York City Council during the day. Have an amazing holiday season & congratulations again ü©∑ - Reese, ‚Äò21




Margaret,
Thank you for everything you have done for me. I am so lucky to have had you for Calc 1 in the fall of 2020. Although I never completed another course with you, you were always there to help me through my other math courses. Even though you had so many other students that you were teaching and had taught prior to teaching me, you still remembered details about me and the details I had shared about my sisters. I loved having you as a professor and as a mentor as I pushed my way through the decision to become a math minor instead of a math major. You were a significant part of my time at MHC as an undergrad and I wish you all the best.
Love,
Evelyn '24




Dear Margaret, I can't believe that it's your last semester teaching at MHC... I still remember vividly the day I reached out to you, kindly asking if you could be my academic advisor! Thank you for being such a wonderful advisor, allowing me and your other advisees/students to make mistakes and grow, and always giving us motherly advice and perspectives to support us during our 4 years at Mount Holyoke and beyond! We are grateful to have had you as our advisor! I hope you enjoy your retirement to the fullest :) ~ Amelia Tran.




Hi Margaret! Hope this message finds you well! This is Sunan and it's been such a long time since we last talked. I can't believe it's been more than five years since I graduated, and I still remember how you patiently answered my discrete math and abstract algebra questions in your office. Actually, it feels like it was just yesterday... You've been such a huge inspiration to me, and you've guided me to love math and to pursue a career rooted in math. I am forever grateful for your help and I am so lucky to be your student! Wishing you all the best in your retirement, and let's keep in touch! :))




Dear Margaret, Thank you for being my "secret mentor" through graduate school!  Even though at the time I had only met you briefly (in the summer of 1997 when I was on a panel for the MHC REU students), you became my go-to contact whenever I was questioning my ability to keep going in my program and to fit into the mathematics world.  In one email response you said that "there was room in mathematics for all different sorts of mathematicians."  That was so powerful that I have shared it many, many times since then with my own students and people that I mentor.  It's been a delight to become your friend over the years, and I wish you all the best in retirement!  Best wishes, Reva Kasman




It was a pleasure having you as an advisor.  You were always upbeat, positive and excited about work.  I wish you an adventure filled retirement.




Dear Margaret - I cannot express my gratitude enough to have you as my faculty advisor and math professor! You are an incredibly kind, loving teacher, always energetic and passionate, and have the best interests of the students in mind! It's been such an honor to be your advisee - you were like a mom to me when I first step my foot on campus in the winter of 2003 as a spring entrant coming all the way from China by myself. You inspired me to get interested in math, become more confident, and helped me kick start a great career in finance afterwards. Thank you for everything! Wish you a happy retirement and starting a new chapter in your life! With lots of love, Sixuan Chen (Class of 2006, Math major)




As you embark on this next chapter of your life, I wanted to take a moment to thank you not only for being an incredible professor but also for being such an inspiring human being. You didn‚Äôt just teach me math‚Äîyou gave me a perspective that I‚Äôve carried with me ever since college.

I still remember coming to your office hours feeling completely overwhelmed by abstract algebra, wondering how others seemed to just know how to solve problems. You reassured me that it‚Äôs not about innate ability but about familiarity and experience‚Äîthe more we encounter and engage with challenges, the more capable we become. That simple wisdom has stayed with me all these years.

Your encouragement and perspective helped me push through not just college but also challenges I‚Äôve faced in my career. Your impact has been profound, and I know countless other students feel the same.

Thank you for everything you‚Äôve given to your students over the years. Wishing you a joyful and fulfilling retirement‚Äîyou‚Äôve more than earned it!





Congratulations on your well-deserved retirement, Professor Robinson! I‚Äôm truly grateful to have had the opportunity to take Linear Algebra with you during my sophomore year‚Äîit was such a memorable and impactful experience. Wishing you all the best in this next chapter! üòä




Hi Professor Robinson! I did not have the opportunity to take many classes with you but I did take your Linear Algebra class in the fall of 2015 and it was one of the best classes I took at Mount Holyoke. When I majored in physical chemistry in grad school, all the lessons (and my notes!) from your class were extremely useful in my quantum classes and now in my career. Thank you for everything and I wish you the best in your future after Mount Holyoke.
Audrey Eshun, '16




You have been an amazing professor and mentor for  future mathematicians and non mathematicians alike. Thank you for being amazing.




Thank you for your amazing work as an educator and mentor. Though I never took a class with you, I feel privileged to have had you as a colleague and friend üß°




Congrats on your very last semester! Thank you for always being our "guiding light" and #standingwithus. Can't wait to celebrate you!




Thank you for highlighting Math in my life! Sending all my best wishes for my favorite Prof!! Hope our paths cross again before too long!




Your magnetic presence in the classroom was unmatched! I wish I could have taken more classes with you but will always cherish the catch ups we had each semester. The field of mathematics is forever changed by your work and mentorship. May retirement bring you much relaxation, joy, and time with those you love.




Margaret, you were the best advisor/professor I could ever ask for. I am sooo lucky to have met you at Mount Holyoke College. I am so sorry I couldn't talk to you this semester earlier after I graduated. Yet, you've been always in my prayers and heart with deep gratitude. I am happy for you to start this new chapter of your life, and I hope it is filled with other things that you love and are passionate about besides math!




The dreams that I dreamed of in your office through our numerous talks have expanded into a lifelong adventure ‚Äî though I'm always feeling a little afraid of the unexpected, it's something I'm willing to face head-on. 
Your wisdom, passion, and care that I experienced during my Moho life have been my inspiration, which I'm forever thankful for. 

Congratulations on your retirement! I wish you all the best throughout your new journey. 

Sending you the deepest gratitude from Korea,
Younghoo Cho '19




Dear Professor Robinson,

Congratulations on your retirement! I wanted to take a moment to express my heartfelt gratitude for the impact you‚Äôve had at Mount Holyoke.

Thank you for making mathematics so joyful and inspiring! You are such a role model, and I feel incredibly fortunate to have learned from you. Your guidance taught me how to persevere in the face of challenges, especially during the pandemic.

The lessons I‚Äôve learned from you‚Äîboth in mathematics and in life‚Äîwill stay with me forever, and for that, I will always be grateful. Thank you for everything you have done for our community and for the support and encouragement you‚Äôve shown along the way.

Best regards,
Yuqi Zhang




Dear Margaret, Happy Retirement! Thank you so much for revealing to me the beauty of mathematics and showing me how to be a generous teacher. I miss your classes. ‚Äì‚ÄìCelia Xu, 18'




Dear Margaret, I have always felt incredibly fortunate to have studied at Mount Holyoke and you are part of the reason why I had an amazing undergraduate experience. I absolutely loved your Abstract Algebra class back in 2008. The way you love teaching and interacting with students inspired me to pursue passionate career of my own. Thank you so much for being a wonderful teacher and role model. Enjoy your well-deserved retirement!  Best, Becky Ding Taylor




Dear Margaret, as you prepare for your well-deserved retirement, I wanted to take a moment to express my gratitude for the impact you've had on my academic journey and personal growth. Your passion for mathematics was inspiring and contagious. I fondly recall our Abstract Algebra class and the other challenging yet rewarding courses I took with you. Your ability to present complex concepts in an engaging and comprehensible way truly made learning a delightful and satisfying adventure. 
I still remember the quotes you put on our take-home exams, for example, the one that went something like "after all the effort, we're still confused but about more difficult problems." I repeated the same to myself the other week after working on a challenging analysis.

I live in Chicago now. I am a Sr Manager for Product Operations and Strategy at a software company called HubSpot. I love my job and the company. It was another Mount Holyoke alumn who recommended me for the interview ~3 years ago! I got married in July ‚Äò22 and baby Jeremy, our first child, arrived this February. It's been a remarkable and joyful year welcoming him into the world and seeing him grow and change so quickly. Let me know if you‚Äôre ever in Chicago or if I can be helpful in any way.
I wish you all the best in your retirement and your future ventures!
With warm regards and gratitude,
Gergana Kostadinova, Class of 2012
413-221-6291. gerganakh@gmail.com




Congratulations Professor Robinson! I really enjoyed having you as a professor for linear algebra, it was one of my favorite math classes! You taught the class so passionately and were so accommodating as I had my concussion and then we were online for COVID (this was Spring 2020). I wish you a happy retirement and hope you are able to spend more time with your family!




Professor Robinson! 

Congratulations on the culmination of an amazing career. Your Linear Algebra class opened my eyes to the beauty of math and the trans-dimensional magic (technical term) of space. Not only did this play a huge role in my thesis work (I am still grateful you agreed to sit on the committee for it), but these concepts have served as valuable building blocks for my creative work in the dance and film sphere.

I hope that you have an amazing retirement and certainly let me know if you find yourself out in the Bay!




Dear Mrs. Robinson (though I suppose now that I am closing in on 50 I could call you Margaret!), I have thought of you so many times over the years. Your Calc 1 class back in 1991 (word problems with rabbits!) was a turning point for me, changing my academic trajectory. I initially took the class to complete a distribution requirement, but somewhere along the way Calculus became beautiful, due in no small part to your enthusiasm. After what was a difficult situation vis a vis mathematics at my high school, you rekindled my love for it and allowed me to consider I may actually be "clever" in this area, as you once told me. I mention you often when talking to younger people about their academic (and life!) choices--to allow for the possibility that beauty and passion and joy may be found in unexpected places, that seeing something through someone else's eyes, as I saw Calculus through yours, may just change them for the better. There is a student I know, likely headed to MHC next year to study mathematics, and though I am saddened to know she won't benefit from the magic of your classroom, I know that the department you were part of shaping, and the many students you inspired over the years, will continue to honor your legacy, and your influence will be felt for generations.
